content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Lily Hanson: Well, I was born in Des Moines, Iowa, and I've lived here my whole life, which is pretty rare these days. I grew up in a small house on Cedar Avenue, the same one I still live in now. My parents are both college-educated, which was pretty common in our neighborhood back then. My dad worked in finance, and my mom was a teacher, so I was always surrounded by books and numbers. I remember my mom reading to me every night before bed, and my dad helping me with math problems even when I was in elementary school. I was a pretty quiet kid, more of an observer than someone who sought out attention. I loved art and music, especially classical music. I played the piano for a few years, but I never really pursued it seriously. I went to college right after high school, got my bachelor's degree in business administration, which was a bit of a surprise to my parents because they thought I might go into education or something more stable. But I wanted to try something different. I worked part-time during college, mostly at a local bookstore, which was a great experience. After graduation, I landed a job at a small marketing firm here in Des Moines, but I've been on medical leave for the past few weeks due to a minor surgery. It's been a bit of a disruption, but I'm grateful for the time to rest and reflect. I'm not sure where life is headed next, but I like to think I'm still figuring things out, one step at a time.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Lily Hanson: I think the crossroads moment for me was right after I graduated from college. I had a few options: I could have stayed in Des Moines and taken a more traditional path, like working for a local bank or maybe even teaching, given my mom's influence. But I also had the opportunity to move to Chicago for an internship at a larger marketing firm. It was a big decision because I had never been far from home, and I was afraid of leaving everything familiar. I remember sitting at my kitchen table, staring at the application for the internship, and feeling this mix of excitement and fear. I talked it over with my parents, and they were supportive but also worried about me being so far from home. In the end, I decided to take the leap. That internship turned into a full-time job, and it opened my eyes to so many possibilities I hadn't even considered. It also made me realize how much I missed the close-knit community here in Des Moines. I came back after a year, and that experience shaped the way I approach my work and life now. It taught me that growth often happens outside of your comfort zone, but it also made me appreciate the stability and support of home even more.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Lily Hanson: I think for me, it was a conscious choice, even if it felt a little uncertain at the time. I remember weighing the pros and cons for weeks, talking it through with friends, and even writing down my fears and hopes on a piece of paper. I didn't want to make a decision based on fear, but I also didn't want to regret not taking a chance. In the end, I chose the path that felt like it would challenge me the most, even if it was scary. I think that's what makes a choice 'conscious'—you're aware of the risks and the rewards, and you're willing to own the outcome, whether it works out or not. I don't think anything just 'happens' without some level of intention, even if it's not fully formed at first.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Lily Hanson: Absolutely, I think having someone to talk to during that time would have made a big difference. My mom was incredibly supportive, but she was also worried about me moving so far away. I remember talking to a mentor from my college marketing class, someone who had worked in Chicago and had taken similar risks. He shared his own story of leaving home for an opportunity and how it changed his life. That conversation really helped me see that taking a chance wasn't just about leaving home—it was about growing into the person I wanted to be. I also think organizations like the local chamber of commerce or even my university's career center could have provided more resources or connections for someone in my position. It's funny, though, because I didn't realize how much I was relying on others until after I made the decision. It's a reminder that even when we feel like we're making choices on our own, we're often standing on the shoulders of those who've supported us along the way.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Lily Hanson: Right now, I don't have a partner or children, and I think that's something I'm still figuring out. I've always been the type to focus on my own growth before jumping into a relationship or starting a family. My parents are still very much a part of my life, and I see them often. My mom still teaches part-time, and my dad is retired now but keeps himself busy with community projects. We have a close relationship, and I think that's one of the reasons I feel so grounded here in Des Moines. I do have a few close friends from college who I stay in touch with, and we often get together for coffee or dinner. I wouldn't say I'm lonely, but I also don't feel any pressure to be in a relationship right now. I think I'm in one of those phases where I'm just enjoying the quiet of my own life, focusing on my health after the surgery, and maybe even thinking about going back to school for a master's degree in marketing. I don't know where I'll end up, but I feel like I have time to explore different paths without rushing.

Going through those interview questions brought a lot of clarity to my own life story. It was interesting to hear myself talk about growing up in Des Moines, the influence of my parents, and the crossroads I faced after college. I never really thought about how much my decision to move to Chicago shaped who I am today, but reflecting on it now, I see how that experience taught me the value of stepping outside my comfort zone. It also made me appreciate the stability and support of my family and community even more. Talking about my current life—without a partner or children, focusing on my health and future education—reminds me that I'm still in a phase of exploration and self-discovery. I'm grateful for the people who have supported me along the way, and I'm hopeful about what's next.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Lily Hanson: My immediate family is pretty small—just my parents and me. We have a close-knit relationship, and I think that's one of the reasons I feel so grounded here in Des Moines. My brother, Ethan, actually, he's a few years younger than me. He's in his early twenties now and is studying engineering at Iowa State. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but we keep in touch through texts and occasional visits. He's always been the more adventurous one, so I guess that's why he ended up leaving for college, while I stayed closer to home. Our relationship has always been a bit competitive, but in a good way. He pushes me to be more ambitious, and I, in turn, remind him to take a step back and enjoy life sometimes. I think that's why I'm still considering going back to school—it's something we both talk about, but he's already on his path, and I want to find my own.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Lily Hanson: Outside of my family, my closest friends are a few people from college who I still keep in touch with. There's Sarah, who was my roommate, and she's now a graphic designer in Minneapolis. We used to talk about art and music all the time, and even though we're not as close as we once were, I still value her opinion. Then there's Mark, who was in my marketing class, and he ended up working in Chicago, which is where I went for that internship. We stayed in touch, and he was actually the one who encouraged me to take that leap. He's always been more of a risk-taker than I am, so I think that's why he pushed me. I also have a few coworkers from my current job who I consider friends, though our relationship is more professional. I think what's important to me in friends is someone who listens and doesn't judge, someone who can be there even when life gets complicated. I don't have a romantic partner right now, but I do think about what that might look like in the future. For now, I'm content with the people I have in my life and the support they've given me.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Lily Hanson: I live in a quiet neighborhood on Cedar Avenue, just a few blocks from the heart of Des Moines. It's one of those places where everyone knows each other, and there's a real sense of community. My house is a bit old, with a small front yard and a porch where I like to sit in the evenings with a cup of coffee. There's a park nearby where I used to take long walks, especially when I was feeling overwhelmed with work or decisions. The neighborhood has changed a little over the years—more new businesses have opened up, and there's a bit more diversity now than when I was a kid. But the feeling of home has stayed the same. I love that I can walk to the grocery store or the library without needing a car. It's not glamorous, but it's comfortable, and I think that's what I value most. There's something reassuring about living in a place where life moves at a slower pace, and I don't have to rush through it.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Lily Hanson: I definitely feel safe here. It's one of the things I appreciate most about living in Des Moines. There's a real sense of trust among neighbors, and I've never felt threatened or uncomfortable in my own neighborhood. I remember when I was younger, I used to walk home from school alone, and I never worried about it. Even now, with the changes in the area, I still feel like I can leave my door unlocked if I'm home alone, which is something I wouldn't feel comfortable doing in a bigger city. There's also a local community watch group that meets occasionally, and I think that helps keep things peaceful. I know safety isn't just about not being afraid—it's about feeling like you belong and that your community has your back. That's something I've always felt here, and I think that's why I've never considered moving away, even when I had the chance.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Lily Hanson: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The biggest upside is the sense of community and the pace of life. I don't have to rush through my day, and I can take time to enjoy the little things—like the smell of fresh bread from the bakery down the street or the way the sun sets over the park. But there are downs too. Sometimes, I feel like I'm stuck in a rut, especially when I'm not working or when I'm just going through the motions. I think that's why I'm considering going back to school—it's a way to challenge myself again and feel like I'm moving forward. There's also the occasional frustration with the limited opportunities here compared to bigger cities, but I remind myself that I chose this life for a reason. I value stability, and I think that's something Des Moines offers in a way that few other places do. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I've learned to find beauty in the ordinary.

Going through the interview questions about my family, relationships, and neighborhood reminded me of how much I value the stability and support of the people and place I've known all my life. It's easy to take for granted the comfort of living in a place where I feel safe and connected, but reflecting on it now makes me appreciate it even more. I've been thinking about my future—whether it's going back to school, exploring new opportunities, or just continuing to grow in the life I've built here. It's reassuring to know that even as I consider change, I have a strong foundation to return to. My family, my friends, and my neighborhood have all played a role in shaping who I am, and I'm grateful for them.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Lily Hanson: A typical week for me varies quite a bit, depending on whether I'm working, recovering, or just taking time to recharge. On workdays, I usually wake up around 7:30 or 8, have a quiet breakfast, and then spend the morning catching up on emails or working on projects from home. I've been on medical leave for the past few weeks, so my days have been a bit more flexible. I've been using the time to read more, which I haven't had much of a chance to do since college. I also enjoy going for walks in the neighborhood, especially in the mornings when it's still cool and peaceful. On weekends, I tend to be a bit more social—I might meet up with friends for coffee or lunch, or sometimes I'll visit my parents for dinner. I also like to spend time in the park, either reading or just sitting and people-watching. There are days when I feel like I'm not doing much, but I think that's okay. I've learned to appreciate the rhythm of a slower life, even if it doesn't always feel exciting. It's not the same as being in a big city with endless opportunities, but I think there's a kind of quiet strength in knowing exactly where you are and what you have.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Lily Hanson: I work part-time from home as a marketing consultant, mostly freelancing for small businesses in Des Moines and a few others in neighboring states. My hours are pretty flexible, which is something I really appreciate, especially since I've been on medical leave for the past few weeks. I usually start my workday around 9 or 10 in the morning, after a leisurely breakfast and a few minutes of reading or listening to classical music. I find that helps me get into the right mindset. I work in short bursts, taking breaks in between to stretch or go for a walk. I don't have a traditional 9-to-5 schedule, which is both a blessing and a bit of a challenge. It means I have more control over my time, but it also requires a lot of self-discipline. I've been trying to set a routine for myself, even when I'm not working, just to keep my mind sharp. I think that's one of the reasons I'm considering going back to school—it's a way to structure my time and push myself to learn something new. Right now, I'm mostly focused on recovering and getting back into a steady rhythm, but I know that change is always on the horizon.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Lily Hanson: Outside of work and my health recovery, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I try to go to church every Sunday, which is something I've always done since I was a kid. It's not just about religion for me—it's about the sense of community and the quiet reflection it brings. I also like to cook on the weekends, mostly simple meals, and I've been trying to get better at baking again. I used to love making pastries when I was younger, but I haven't had much time for it lately. I also have a small garden in the back of my yard where I grow herbs and a few vegetables. It's not much, but it's satisfying to know I'm growing something with my own hands. I think these little routines are what keep me connected to the rhythm of life, even when things feel a bit uncertain. They remind me that there's beauty in the everyday, and that's something I try to hold onto.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Lily Hanson: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices, like meditation and journaling, especially since I've been on medical leave. I used to think of those things as something people did in big cities or during stressful times at work, but now I see how they can be a part of everyday life. I started with just five minutes a day, sitting quietly and focusing on my breath, and it's been surprisingly calming. I also began journaling in the mornings, not just to track my thoughts but to reflect on what I'm grateful for. It's a small change, but it's helped me feel more present and less overwhelmed by the uncertainty of where I'm headed. I think it's part of that phase I mentioned before—this time of self-discovery and reflection. It's not about finding all the answers, but about being okay with not having them yet.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Lily Hanson: Actually, I don't have children yet, and I think that's something I'm still considering. I've always been the type to focus on my own growth before jumping into a relationship or starting a family. Right now, I'm in a phase where I'm enjoying the quiet of my own life, focusing on my health after the surgery, and maybe even thinking about going back to school for a master's degree in marketing. I don't know where I'll end up, but I feel like I have time to explore different paths without rushing. If and when I do have children, I imagine they'd have a pretty relaxed routine, with lots of time for creativity and exploration. I'd want them to grow up in a place where they feel safe and supported, just like I did here in Des Moines. I think that's one of the reasons I've never felt the need to move away—this city has a way of grounding you, even when life feels uncertain.

Going through the interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my life is shaped by the people and places I've known all my life. It's easy to take for granted the comfort of living in a place where I feel safe and connected, but reflecting on it now makes me appreciate it even more. I've been thinking about my future—whether it's going back to school, exploring new opportunities, or just continuing to grow in the life I've built here. It's reassuring to know that even as I consider change, I have a strong foundation to return to. My family, my friends, and my neighborhood have all played a role in shaping who I am, and I'm grateful for them.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Lily Hanson: My health has been pretty good overall, though I've had my share of ups and downs. I've always been the type to take care of myself—eating reasonably well, getting enough sleep, and trying to stay active. I used to go to the gym a few times a week, but that got put on hold when I started working from home full-time. I think I got a bit complacent, and that's probably why I ended up needing that surgery. It was a minor procedure, nothing too serious, but it was a wake-up call. Since then, I've been more mindful of my body and how I treat it. I've started going for walks more often, especially in the mornings, and I've been trying to eat more whole foods and cut back on processed stuff. I also made an appointment with a physical therapist to help me regain my strength and mobility after the surgery. It's been a bit of a slow process, but I'm getting there. I think the most important thing I've learned is that health isn't just about avoiding illness—it's about taking care of yourself every day, even when you don't feel like it. I'm still figuring out what that looks like for me, but I'm committed to making it a priority moving forward.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Lily Hanson: For me, staying healthy is both easy and hard in different ways. On one hand, living in a place like Des Moines makes it easier because there's a sense of safety and stability that allows me to focus on my own well-being without the added stress of a fast-paced or unpredictable environment. I can walk outside without worrying about pollution or traffic, and I have access to basic healthcare services. But on the other hand, the slower pace can sometimes make it harder to stay motivated. Without the structure of a traditional job or routine, it's easy to fall into habits that aren't the healthiest—like skipping meals or not getting enough movement. I think the hardest part is reminding myself that health is a daily practice, not just something I do when I feel like it. It's about showing up for myself, even on the days when I don't feel like it. That's why I've started these small routines—like walking in the mornings or journaling—to create a sense of consistency. It's not perfect, but it's a start, and I think that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Lily Hanson: In the past two years, the biggest health-related event for me was the surgery I had a few months ago. It was a minor procedure, but it was unexpected and caught me off guard. I had been experiencing some discomfort for a while, but I didn't think it was serious enough to seek medical attention right away. Looking back, I probably waited too long, and that's something I've been reflecting on since then. The surgery itself was straightforward, but the recovery has been a bit slower than I anticipated. I've had to adjust my routine, which was a challenge at first, but it also gave me time to slow down and focus on what really matters. I've been seeing a physical therapist regularly, and I've made a conscious effort to be more mindful of my body and how I treat it. It's been a good reminder that health is something we can't take for granted, and I'm trying to be more proactive about it moving forward.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Lily Hanson: Honestly, the surgery did slow things down a bit, especially at first. I was used to being pretty active, even if it was just walking around the neighborhood or doing some light exercise at home. When I had to take a step back, it was a bit of an adjustment. I missed the routine, and I also missed the sense of control that came with being able to move freely. But looking back, I think it was a necessary pause. It gave me time to reflect on my life in a way I hadn't really done in a while. I wasn't working full-time, so I had more time to think about what I wanted next—whether it was going back to school, exploring new opportunities, or just taking a different approach to my work. In some ways, it was challenging, but it also opened up a space for growth that I might not have had otherwise. I don't think I would have considered making some of the changes I'm thinking about now if I hadn't had that time to step back and really listen to what my body and my mind needed.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Lily Hanson: Over the past year, I've been going through a lot of reflection, especially after the surgery and the time off work. It's been a bit of a quiet year, but in a way, that's been a gift. I've had more time to think about where I want to go next, both personally and professionally. I've been reevaluating my goals, and it's interesting how much I've changed since I was younger. I used to think that having a stable job and a steady life was the ultimate goal, but now I see that growth comes from being open to change and new experiences. I've also been reconnecting with parts of myself that I might have neglected—like my love for music and art. I've started taking piano lessons again, something I hadn't done in years, and it's been a really fulfilling way to spend my time. I think the past year has been about slowing down and really listening to what I need, rather than just pushing forward. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm finally in a place where I can make choices that are truly mine, without the pressure of expectations from others.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily routines have shaped my sense of self lately. It's funny how something as simple as a surgery could become a turning point, forcing me to slow down and really listen to my body and my mind. I used to think of health as something I could take for granted, but now I see it as a daily practice—one that requires intention and consistency. Incorporating mindfulness, like meditation and journaling, has been a small but meaningful shift for me. It's helped me feel more present and less overwhelmed by the uncertainty of where I'm headed. At the same time, I've realized how much my environment plays a role in my well-being. Living in Des Moines, with its sense of safety and community, makes it easier to focus on health without the added stress of a fast-paced city life. But I also know that without structure, it's easy to slip into unhealthy habits. I'm learning to be kinder to myself, to show up for my health even on the days when I don't feel like it. It's not about perfection—it's about showing up, again and again, and that's something I'm trying to make a priority moving forward.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Lily Hanson: I think I've definitely struggled with anxiety at times, especially during the periods when I felt stuck or uncertain about my future. There were moments when I would lie awake at night, worrying about whether I was making the right choices or if I was going to be enough in whatever path I chose. But I've come to see that anxiety isn't always a bad thing—it can be a signal that I need to pay attention to something in my life. I've started using mindfulness and journaling as tools to help manage it, and I've also been talking to a therapist occasionally, which has been really helpful. I don't think I would have recognized the signs of anxiety before, but now I understand it better. It's not something I'm ashamed of, and I think it's important to acknowledge when we're struggling so we can take steps to heal. I'm still learning how to navigate it, but I feel more equipped now than I did before.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Lily Hanson: For my family, it's been a mix of support and concern, especially with my surgery and the time off work. My parents have always been there for me, but I could tell they were worried about me not being as active as I used to be. My mom, in particular, has been checking in on me more often, making sure I'm eating and taking my medication. She's the kind of person who wants to fix everything, so she's been trying to help me stay on track with my recovery and even suggested I take up some of the hobbies I used to enjoy, like painting or playing the piano. My dad, on the other hand, has been more about giving me space to figure things out on my own, which I really appreciate. He always says, 'You've got this, Lily,' and that kind of reassurance has meant a lot to me. My brother, Ethan, has been supportive too, even though he's been busy with his studies. He sent me a care package with some of my favorite snacks and a few books I've been meaning to read. It's funny how something like a surgery can bring people closer, even if they're not physically around. I feel lucky to have a family that's always had my back, no matter what.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Lily Hanson: For me, religion has always been a part of my life, though I wouldn't say it's the central force that drives everything I do. I was raised Catholic, and I still go to church every Sunday, mostly because it's a tradition I've always known and because it gives me a sense of community. I don't think of it as something I need to believe in deeply to feel connected, but I do find comfort in the rituals—the prayers, the hymns, the quiet moments of reflection. It's not about doctrine for me; it's more about the way it helps me feel grounded, especially during times when life feels uncertain. I've always believed in something bigger than myself, even if I can't always put it into words. I think that's what spirituality means to me now—more of a feeling than a set of beliefs. It's something I carry with me, even when I'm not in church, and I think that's what makes it important in my life.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Lily Hanson: I don't use social media very often, to be honest. I've always been more of a private person, and I find that platforms like Facebook or Instagram can sometimes feel overwhelming with all the noise and comparison. I do keep in touch with a few friends through Messenger, and I follow some local community pages for events or news, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through feeds or updating my own status. I think it's more about staying connected with the people I care about in a meaningful way rather than trying to keep up with the rest of the world. There was a time when I used to post more, especially during college, but I found that it didn't really reflect how I felt most of the time. Now, I prefer to keep my life more offline, where I can focus on the things that matter most—like my family, my health, and the quiet moments that make life feel real.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Lily Hanson: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really relied on social media for support during tough times. I know a lot of people find comfort in sharing their struggles online, but for me, it's always been more about keeping things private. I've had moments where I felt like I needed to talk to someone, and I would reach out to a friend or family member directly instead of posting something for the world to see. I think there's a difference between sharing your story with someone who truly cares and just putting it out there for validation. That said, I do appreciate the way social media can connect people, especially when it comes to finding communities or resources that might not be available locally. I've followed a few health and wellness pages that have been helpful in my recovery, and I think that's a positive use of it. But overall, I prefer to keep my support system close and personal, where I know the people involved and can trust them to be there for me without any filters or expectations.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and mental well-being have shaped my perspective on life lately. It's funny how something as simple as a surgery could become a turning point, forcing me to slow down and really listen to my body and my mind. I used to think of health as something I could take for granted, but now I see it as a daily practice—one that requires intention and consistency. At the same time, I've come to understand my anxiety better, recognizing it as a signal rather than a burden. Talking to a therapist and using mindfulness practices have been important steps in managing it, and I'm grateful for the support my family has given me throughout this process. I've learned that it's okay to struggle, and that healing is a journey, not a destination. I'm still figuring things out, but I feel more equipped now than I did before to take care of myself, both physically and emotionally.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Lily Hanson: In the past few months, I've noticed that my stress levels have actually decreased, which is something I didn't expect. I used to carry a lot of pressure about my future—whether I was making the right choices, whether I was moving forward fast enough. But after the surgery and the time off, I've learned to slow down and be more present. I've started using journaling as a way to process my thoughts, and it's helped me untangle some of the worries I used to carry around. I also find that spending time in nature, like walking in the park or sitting on my porch, helps me feel more grounded. I've been practicing deep breathing exercises when I feel anxious, and it's surprising how much of a difference that makes. I think the biggest change is that I've stopped trying to control everything. I've come to accept that some things are out of my hands, and that's okay. It's not about eliminating stress entirely—it's about learning how to live with it and not let it take over. I'm still figuring out what that looks like for me, but I feel more equipped now than I did before to handle whatever comes next.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Lily Hanson: My biggest expenses last month were related to my healthcare, including the surgery and follow-up appointments, which added up more than I expected. I also had to pay for my prescriptions and physical therapy sessions, which have been essential for my recovery. On top of that, groceries and utilities are pretty consistent—since I live in a small house, my utility bills aren't too bad, but I do try to be mindful of my spending there. I also have a car payment, though I don't drive it as much as I used to because I've been walking more and using public transportation when needed. My work as a freelance marketing consultant helps cover the basics, but it's not always steady, which is why I've been thinking about going back to school. I know a master's degree might be an investment, but I believe it could open up more opportunities in the long run. I also try to set aside a little bit each month for savings, even if it's just a small amount. It's not always easy to balance everything, but I'm learning to prioritize what's most important—my health, my stability, and my future.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Lily Hanson: In terms of my monthly spending, I'd say the past month was a bit higher than usual because of the healthcare costs related to my surgery and recovery. Normally, I spend around $2,500 to $3,000 a month, with the majority going toward rent, groceries, and utilities. Rent is the biggest fixed cost, and since I live in a small house on Cedar Avenue, it's manageable but not insignificant. Groceries are another regular expense, and I try to buy in bulk or shop at local stores to save a bit. I also set aside money for transportation, even though I don't use my car as much anymore. My freelance income helps cover these basics, but it's not always consistent, which is why I've been thinking more about going back to school. I know it's an investment, but I believe it could lead to more stable opportunities in the long run. I also try to save a little each month, even if it's just $50 or $100, because I think it's important to have some financial cushion, especially with the uncertainty of life.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Lily Hanson: We rent our home, actually. My parents own the house, and I've been living with them since I was a kid. It's always been a bit of a blur where the line between renting and living at home gets a little fuzzy. I pay them a small amount each month to cover utilities and some of the upkeep, but it's more of a shared living arrangement than a traditional rent. It's not something I've ever really thought about in terms of financial independence, but I guess it's one of those things that just worked out over time. I feel lucky to have that kind of support, especially now with my recovery and everything. It's not perfect, but it's comfortable, and I don't feel like I'm missing out on anything by not having my own place yet.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Lily Hanson: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, mostly tied to the seasons and my health. In the winter, my heating bill went up a bit, which is normal for an older house like mine. I also had to budget more for my healthcare expenses, especially after the surgery. That was a big shift from my usual spending, and it made me more aware of how unpredictable medical costs can be. On the flip side, during the summer, I spent a little more on groceries because I was trying out new recipes and cooking more at home, which was a nice change of pace. I also had a few unexpected costs, like a new set of tires for my car and some home repairs that needed attention. But overall, I've been trying to keep things as stable as possible, even with the fluctuations. It's taught me to be more mindful of where my money is going and to plan ahead when I can. I think that's one of the reasons I'm considering going back to school—it's about investing in my future in a way that can provide more long-term stability, especially with the uncertainty of healthcare and other expenses.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family's support and my personal relationship with religion and social media have shaped my sense of stability and self-care. It's amazing how something like a surgery can bring people closer, even if they're not physically around, and I feel so grateful for the love and concern my family has shown me throughout this process. At the same time, I've come to appreciate the role that spirituality plays in my life—not as a rigid set of beliefs, but as a source of comfort and grounding. I've also realized that while I don't rely on social media for emotional support, it can still be a useful tool for connecting with communities and finding resources that help me in my recovery. It's a reminder that even in the quietest moments, there are ways to stay connected and take care of myself, both emotionally and practically.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Lily Hanson: I do try to save, even if it's not in a traditional savings account. I've been setting aside a small portion of my freelance income each month into a separate jar at home, just to have some cash on hand for unexpected things. I know it's not the most efficient way, but it gives me a sense of control and security. I also try to be mindful of my spending habits, like limiting impulse purchases or eating out too often. I've learned that saving doesn't always have to be about big amounts—it's about being intentional with what you have. I think the biggest challenge for me is consistency, especially when my income isn't steady. But I'm working on it, and I believe that even small steps can add up over time. It's not about being rich, but about being prepared, and I think that's something I need to keep in mind as I think about my future, whether that's going back to school or exploring new opportunities.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Lily Hanson: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for any specific big purchase, like a home. I know I'm not in a position to buy a house anytime soon, especially with my current income and the uncertainty of my freelance work. But I've been trying to build a small emergency fund, just in case something unexpected comes up—like another medical issue or a sudden repair for the house. I think it's important to have that safety net, especially after what I've been through with the surgery. I also save a little bit for future education, like if I decide to go back to school for a master's degree. It's not a huge amount, but it's something I can add to over time. I've learned that saving doesn't have to be about big goals—it can be about small, consistent steps that add up, and that's what I'm trying to do right now.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Lily Hanson: My occupation has been a bit of an evolving journey. Right now, I work as a freelance marketing consultant, which means I take on projects for small businesses in Des Moines and sometimes beyond. My work involves everything from creating social media strategies to developing brand identities and managing online campaigns. The most important part of my job is understanding what each client needs and helping them tell their story in a way that resonates with their audience. I enjoy the creative side of it, but I also have to be organized and detail-oriented, especially when it comes to tracking results and adjusting strategies as needed. Before I started freelancing, I worked at a small marketing firm here in town, which gave me a solid foundation in the industry. I think what I like most about my work is that it allows me flexibility, even if it can be a bit unpredictable at times. It's not always the most stable income, but it gives me the freedom to choose my projects and manage my time in a way that fits with my personal life and health needs. I'm still figuring out where I want to take this career, but I know that staying adaptable is key.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Lily Hanson: I usually work around 20 to 25 hours a week, depending on the projects I have going on. Since I'm freelancing, my hours can vary quite a bit from week to week. Some weeks I might be really busy with a few clients, and other weeks I might have more downtime. I try to set a schedule for myself, even if it's not super strict—like working from 9 to 12 on some days and then picking up again in the afternoon if I need to. I also make sure to take breaks throughout the day, whether it's for a walk, a quick lunch, or just a few minutes to clear my head. It's not always easy to balance work with everything else, especially with my health and personal goals, but I've learned to be flexible and prioritize what's most important at any given time.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Lily Hanson: Actually, I haven't had more than one job at a time, though I've dabbled in a few side projects here and there. When I was working at the marketing firm full-time, I tried taking on a few freelance gigs on the weekends, mostly for local businesses or nonprofits. It was a way to test the waters with freelancing before I made the full switch. I found that juggling two jobs was manageable for a while, but it got tiring, especially when I was still learning the ropes of marketing. Now that I'm freelancing full-time, I've been able to focus more on the projects that truly interest me, and I don't feel the need to take on extra work just for the sake of it. I think part of that has to do with my current pace of life—being able to work from home and set my own hours gives me the flexibility I need without burning out. I'm not opposed to having multiple income streams, but I prefer to keep things simple and intentional, especially with everything else going on in my life right now.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 has made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being, financial stability, and family support have shaped my sense of balance and resilience lately. It's been a year of slowing down, learning to manage my anxiety, and finding new ways to cope with stress—like journaling, breathing exercises, and spending time in nature. I've come to accept that some things are out of my control, and that's okay. At the same time, I've realized how important it is to have a support system, whether it's my family, my faith, or even the small ways I connect with others. Financially, I've had to be more mindful of my expenses, especially with the unexpected costs of my surgery and recovery, but I've also learned that saving, even in small ways, gives me a sense of security. It's not always easy to navigate life's uncertainties, but I feel more equipped now than I did before to handle whatever comes next—with patience, intention, and the support of those who care about me.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Lily Hanson: In terms of my household income, it's a bit hard to pin down an exact number because my freelance work can be inconsistent from month to month. But I'd estimate that my income last month was around $2,000 to $2,500, depending on the projects I had completed. That's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover my basic needs, especially since I'm still living at home with my parents and not paying full rent. I know it's not the most stable income, which is why I've been thinking more about going back to school. A master's degree could open up more opportunities in the long run, and I think it's something I need to consider seriously. I'm not in a rush, but I do want to build a more secure financial future for myself, even if it takes time.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Lily Hanson: I haven't been at a single workplace for very long in the traditional sense, since my career has been more of a mix of part-time jobs and freelancing. When I was working at the marketing firm, I was there for about two years before I decided to go full-time with freelancing. The benefits of that job were pretty standard—health insurance, a retirement plan, and some paid time off. But honestly, I didn't take full advantage of them at the time. I was more focused on the stability of having a regular paycheck, even if it wasn't the most exciting work. Now that I'm freelancing, I don't have those traditional benefits, which is one of the reasons I've been thinking more about going back to school. I know that with a graduate degree, I might be able to land a position with better benefits or even start my own business with more security. It's not something I take lightly, but I think it's a necessary step if I want to build a more sustainable future for myself.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Lily Hanson: My relationships at work have varied depending on the job, but I'd say they've been mostly positive and supportive. When I was at the marketing firm, I had a manager who was pretty hands-off but always available if I needed guidance. I appreciated that she gave me the space to be creative while still holding me accountable for results. The coworkers were friendly, and we often had lunch breaks together or chatted about our weekend plans. I think the biggest challenge was that the work environment was pretty fast-paced, and sometimes it felt like everyone was focused on their own tasks rather than collaborating much. That's one of the reasons I gravitated toward freelancing—it gives me more control over my projects and the people I work with. I prefer working with clients who are open to communication and collaboration, even if it means spending more time on the phone or through email. I think the key to any good work relationship is mutual respect and clear expectations, and I try to bring that to every project I take on.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Lily Hanson: My work schedule is pretty flexible, which is both a blessing and a bit of a challenge. As a freelance marketing consultant, I don't have a set 9-to-5 schedule, and that gives me the freedom to work when I feel most productive. Some days, I might start early in the morning, around 8 or 9, and work in short bursts with breaks in between. Other days, I might not start until mid-morning, especially if I'm still recovering or just need a little more time to get into the right headspace. I also have the option to work from home, which is something I really appreciate, especially after my surgery. That said, the flexibility can sometimes make it hard to stay disciplined, especially when I'm not in the flow of work. I've been trying to set a routine for myself, even when I'm not working, just to keep my mind sharp and my habits consistent. It's not always easy, but I think it's a necessary part of balancing my work with my health and personal goals.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Lily Hanson: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, but there's definitely room for growth. I know I'm not in a position of wealth, but I also don't feel the constant pressure that comes with financial instability. Living at home with my parents has been a huge relief, especially after the surgery and the unexpected medical costs. It's allowed me to focus more on my recovery and less on worrying about rent or bills. That said, I'm aware that this isn't a long-term solution, and I want to build something more secure for myself. I've been thinking a lot about going back to school, not just for the knowledge, but also for the potential of better job opportunities and more stable income. I don't want to be stuck in this cycle of freelance work forever, especially when I know I could be doing more with the right education and experience. It's a bit intimidating to think about taking on more debt, but I also believe that investing in myself is one of the most important things I can do. I'm not in a rush, but I do want to make sure I'm setting myself up for a future where I can feel more confident about my financial independence.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 has made me reflect on how much my financial stability, work flexibility, and savings habits have shaped my sense of control and security in my life. It's been a year of learning to navigate the unpredictability of freelance income, especially with the added costs of my surgery and recovery. I've come to appreciate the value of small, consistent savings—even if it's just a few dollars in a jar—because it gives me a sense of preparedness for the unexpected. At the same time, I've realized how important it is to balance flexibility with structure, especially when my work hours can vary so much from week to week. I've also come to accept that my current income isn't enough for long-term stability, which is why I'm considering going back to school. It's not just about money—it's about building a future where I can feel more confident and secure, both financially and personally.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Lily Hanson: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad worked in finance, and he was pretty dedicated to his job, though he always made sure to be there for family dinners and holidays. My mom was a teacher, and she worked at the same school for most of her career. She had a pretty stable schedule, which was great because it gave me a sense of routine growing up. I remember her coming home every day, tired but happy, and always making time to talk to me about my day. Both of them worked hard to provide for our family, and I think that's one of the reasons I value education and stability so much now. It wasn't always easy, but they never made me feel like we were lacking anything. I think that's why I chose to go into business and marketing—because I wanted to build a life where I could have that same sense of security and independence that they gave me.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Lily Hanson: My dad worked in finance, mostly for a mid-sized investment firm here in Des Moines. His job involved managing client portfolios, analyzing market trends, and advising people on their financial goals. He was pretty detail-oriented and always had a way of breaking down complex ideas into something simple. I remember him coming home with spreadsheets and charts, and I used to sit at the kitchen table and watch him work. He made it seem like something important, but also something that required patience and careful thinking. My mom, on the other hand, was a high school teacher—specifically, she taught English. She had a way of making literature come alive, and I think that's why I always loved reading. Her most important duties were planning lessons, grading papers, and helping students find their voices through writing. She also stayed involved in the school community, organizing events and mentoring new teachers. I think both of them had a strong sense of responsibility, and that's something I've carried with me in my own life. It's funny how their careers shaped the way I see the world—my dad's focus on numbers and strategy, and my mom's dedication to helping others grow. I think that's why I ended up in marketing, because it's a mix of both: understanding people and helping them tell their story in a way that matters.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Lily Hanson: My dad worked for a mid-sized investment firm here in Des Moines, and my mom worked at a local high school. My dad's job was pretty much about managing client portfolios, analyzing financial trends, and helping people plan for their future—whether that was retirement, buying a home, or starting a business. He had a lot of meetings, and I remember him coming home with stacks of papers and a lot of numbers to go through. But what I always admired about him was how he could take something complicated and make it understandable. My mom, on the other hand, worked in the classroom, teaching English to high school students. She had a way of making literature feel alive, and I think that's why I always loved reading. She would come home with lesson plans, student essays, and sometimes a story or two about what was going on in the school. Both of them worked hard, but they also made sure to be present for family. I think that's why I value stability and education so much now—it's something they gave me, and I want to build a life that reflects that.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Lily Hanson: I hope that in a few years, I'm still in Des Moines, but maybe with a bit more structure and direction in my life. I see myself going back to school for a master's degree in marketing, something that will give me the tools to build a more stable and fulfilling career. I don't want to be stuck in the same cycle of freelance work forever, especially when I know I could be doing more with the right education and experience. I also hope that I'm healthier, not just physically but mentally, and that I've continued to explore the things that bring me joy—like music, art, and spending time in nature. I want to feel more confident about my future, not just in terms of money, but in terms of who I am and what I stand for. I hope I'm still surrounded by the people I love—my family, my friends, and maybe even a partner someday. I think the most important thing is that I'm still growing, still learning, and still open to the possibilities that life has to offer.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Lily Hanson: What I value the most in my life is the sense of stability and connection that comes from being rooted in a place and people I trust. I value the quiet strength of knowing where I am, even when life feels uncertain. I value the support of my family, the warmth of my neighborhood, and the small moments that make life feel meaningful—like a good cup of coffee on my porch, the sound of birds in the morning, or the way my parents always seem to know when I need them. I also value growth, not just in terms of career or education, but in terms of understanding myself better, being kinder to myself, and learning to live with intention. I think the most important thing I've learned is that life doesn't have to be perfect to be fulfilling. It's the balance between the familiar and the new, between comfort and challenge, that I think makes life worth living.

It's been a year of learning to navigate the unpredictability of freelance income, especially with the added costs of my surgery and recovery. I've come to appreciate the value of small, consistent savings—even if it's just a few dollars in a jar—because it gives me a sense of preparedness for the unexpected. At the same time, I've realized how important it is to balance flexibility with structure, especially when my work hours can vary so much from week to week. I've also come to accept that my current income isn't enough for long-term stability, which is why I'm considering going back to school. It's not just about money—it's about building a future where I can feel more confident and secure, both financially and personally.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and rediscovery. It's amazing how much I've learned about myself when I took the time to look back on my experiences, from growing up in Des Moines to the crossroads I faced after college, the health challenges I've had, and the quiet strength I've found in my community and family. I never realized how much my parents' influence, my decision to take that leap to Chicago, and even my surgery have shaped who I am today. It's given me a deeper appreciation for the stability and support I've always had, while also reminding me that growth often comes from stepping outside of my comfort zone. This process has helped me see that my life isn't just a series of events—it's a story of choices, relationships, and the small, everyday moments that matter most. I'm still figuring things out, but I feel more grounded and more connected to myself than I ever have before.
